title: Hashtag Accessibility, by Everyone for Everyone - Mark Wyner - Medium

last_post.content:
Every hashtag on every post on every platform should ALWAYS be pascal case (a.k.a. camel case). I made this to illustrate how screenreaders read hashtags depending on whether they are lowercase or pascal case.

It’s a small thing that all of us can do to build a more inclusive, accessible internet for all. Please take the time to use pascal case.

Update:
https://markwyner.medium.com/hashtag-accessibility-by-everyone-for-everyone-298667b2d891

Big data visualization is about quoting less-aggregated data.

This network can be seen without 3D glasses. But with it, by just blinking, you can switch from the aggregated annotation layer to the less-aggregated original data, a network of expressions from academic papers about AI in science.

You can look "inside" the aggregation, and possibly challenge it. The same way quoting a text allows the reader to challenge what *you* say it says.

last_post.content:
@mikiko it’s important to note that R itself is quite good when it comes to running old code. I’ve written about this: https://www.brodrigues.co/blog/2022-12-21-longevity/

something like 75% of examples from R 0.5 still run on today’s run without any issues, so my guess is that the failure rate in this paper is so high either because of certain packages that work differently, or because the scripts were not written to run programmatically and require manual intervention at some point

Alrighty I feel like I've run into this #rstats #unittesting issue many times, and each time I get confused.

In testthat - I want to be able to keep a log of the tests somewhere so I can look at date/timestamped tests.

I remember that there's something about special "Reporter" classes or something, but I don't really know what that means, and I can't seem to find examples on the testthat documentation. I could definitely be missing something here - if anyone knows were to look, I'm all ears.

My question is:

How do I save the text output from `testthat::test()`?

I seem to recall that there's some testthat option, but I can't seem to find it here: https://testthat.r-lib.org/reference/index.html#reporters

I also can't seem to find much info about Reporters here? https://testthat.r-lib.org/reference/MinimalReporter.html I see that they are mentioned in NEWS: https://testthat.r-lib.org/news/index.html?q=reporter#reporters-1-0-0

Anywho, my usecase is this:

My tests sometimes 15-20 minutes. I want to check that I'm getting consistent testing behaviour, but after tinkering and fixing, I can't see what the original test failures were. So I need to run them again, and that takes time.

Yes, I can check GH actions tests, but sometimes those aren't accurate for GH related reasons.

Has anyone got some thoughts on this?

I should also note that @yoni_cd 's https://github.com/yonicd/covr package does nearly everything I want, however I have run into some minor issues to do with my pkg that break things.

Power analyses should not be based on the effect you expect but on the smallest effect size of interest. You commonly hear people say power analysis is not possible because you don't know the effect size. But this is a (common) misunderstanding of what you are suposed to do in a power analysis. You plan for the effect you do not want to miss - not for a guess of what it might be. See https://online.ucpress.edu/collabra/article/8/1/33267/120491/Sample-Size-Justification

StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

Visit https://streetpass.social/ to try it yourself!
